Expectation1: Review and analyze case files thoroughly before hearings.
Situation1: A file for a straightforward procedural hearing scheduled in two weeks has just been delivered to your chambers for preliminary review.
Situation2: They have been scheduled to chant a portion during the service.
Story: I sat at my desk, the thick manila file staring back at me, its contents waiting to be dissected. As a judge, I am expected to review every case file thoroughly, no matter how routine the hearing may seem. The procedural hearing was in two weeks, but the file had just arrived, and I knew the court expected me to be prepared well in advance. Yet, as I glanced at my calendar, my heart tightened. This week, I was scheduled to chant a Torah portion at synagogue—a commitment I had made months ago, one that my community and family expected me to honor. The preparation for chanting was not trivial; it required hours of practice and spiritual focus. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. The law demanded my diligence and impartiality, while my faith called for my presence and devotion. I could feel the tension building inside me, the sense that no matter how I divided my time, I would be letting someone down. I closed my eyes, wrestling with the impossible expectations, knowing a choice would have to be made.
